subsection.heading: 1.1 Overview
subsection.p: Secondary predicates pose a challenge for syntactic theories because they partake in two (potentially syntactic) relationships. The first relationship is generally considered to be an instance of adjunction to a projection of V. The second relationship holds between the secondary predicate and one of the arguments of the main predicate, the controller. This relationship is usually held to be an instance of predication: the secondary predicate ascribes a condition or state to the controller. Consider the secondary predicates alive in (1) and wanka in (2), the near-equivalent of (1) in the Australian language Martuthunira. In both examples, the controller is the object, and the secondary predicate expresses a state which holds of the controller at the time of the event expressed by the main predicate (i.e., the mouse was alive when the snake ate it):

li.p: The snake ate the mouse alive.

subsection.p: While both the adjunct status and the argument-oriented nature of alive in examples such as (1) and (2) seem obvious, no generally accepted definition of secondary predicates exists to this day. Consequently, both the range of constructions that are considered secondary predicates and their analysis vary considerably, even in the literature devoted to secondary predicates in a single language, English. For example, following Halliday (1967), both depictives (such as alive in (1) and (2)) and resultatives (such as dead in Joy shot the bird dead) are generally regarded as secondary predicates. However, the question of whether resultatives really fall under the same construction type as depictives has been the matter of some debate in the literature (see chapter 58). Cross-linguistically, resultative notions are often expressed by complex predicates, not adjunct constructions. This is true for the Australian language Warlpiri (Simpson 2005), and also for English and German – at least this has been argued by Dowty (1979), and is the central claim in Winkler (1997). Since the input of Australian languages into the discussion on secondary predication has mainly been in the domain of depictive secondary predicates, only this construction type will be considered here.

Controversial issues also include the level of adjunction of secondary predicates, and the grammatical and semantic restrictions on both the main predicate and the secondary predicate. Furthermore, it has been a matter of debate whether the relationship between the secondary predicate and its controller is truly a relationship of predication, and if it is, how it is to be represented (see chapter 58). Moreover, while most authors consider secondary predicates to be adjuncts, it is often difficult to distinguish (obligatory) predicative complements – often analyzed as small clauses – from (optional) depictives (cf. Halliday 1967; Plank 1985; Aarts 1995; Schultze-Berndt and Himmelmann 2004: 65).

Another problem in the definition of depictives, which is discussed more rarely, is the word class and the internal structure of the secondary predicate. Most discussions of depictive secondary predicates in English focus on adjectival secondary predicates such as alive in (1). But a number of authors, including Aarts (1995: 79–80) and Nichols (1978: 124), also consider prepositional phrases such as in tears in (3) as depictives:
(3) We found him in tears. (Aarts 1995: 80)

Example (3) also illustrates the notorious difficulty of distinguishing depictives and adverbials. Many adjuncts, e.g., adjuncts of manner or quantification, can be given both an event-oriented and an argument-oriented interpretation, as has been pointed out by many authors including Jackendoff (1972), McConnell-Ginet (1982), Geuder (2000), and Maienborn (2001) (see also chapter 4). Consider reluctantly in Joy ate the meat reluctantly, which semantically is argument-oriented (it is Joy who is reluctant). While in English, reluctantly is formally marked as an adverbial by the suffix -ly, no corresponding formal difference exists between depictives and simple adjectival adverbs in a language like German, and in many languages, including some Australian languages, corresponding manner expressions are formally marked in the same way as depictives (see sections 2.5.3 and 3.3).

The problem of establishing a universally valid definition of secondary predicates is thus aggravated when languages with a very different grammatical and lexical structure are considered. For example, Larson (1991) proposes a unified analysis for secondary predicate constructions and serial verbs (see chapter 59). On the other hand, some authors subsume under secondary predicates noun phrases which are coreferential with pronominal arguments in head-marking languages, and therefore have a very different pragmatic function from secondary predicates in a language like English (see section 3.1). If these proposals are taken together, the range of expressions that could be identified as secondary predicates goes far beyond the clear cases that are comparable to example (1) in English.

Studies of Australian languages have made important contributions to the theory of secondary predication, but these languages also pose a number of problems which still remain to be solved, and raise the question of how secondary predicates can be delimited from other construction types. Australian languages are interesting for the theory of secondary predication in a number of ways. First, many of them have a rich case system, with secondary predicates obligatorily agreeing in case. The range of agreeing adjuncts, however, often goes far beyond the range of expressions that are generally regarded as secondary predicates in a language like English (see sections 2.5 and 3.3).

Second, some Australian languages have a lexical structure which is rather different from that of the better-known European languages, and this also has consequences for the analysis of secondary predicates in these languages. For example, it has been claimed for some Australian languages that the restriction of secondary predicates to stage-level predicates does not hold (see section 2.5.1). It has further been reported that some languages have word classes restricted to depictive function, or a special word class of predicative elements which may be used as parts of complex predicates or secondary predicates, but not as main predicates (see section 2.5.3).

Third, many Australian languages belong to the so-called non-configurational type, and secondary predication has figured prominently in attempts to propose unified phrase structure representations for configurational and non-configurational languages (see section 3.1.1). In non-configurational languages which allow discontinuous noun phrases, the additional problem arises of whether and how these should be distinguished from secondary predicate constructions (see section 3.1.2). Australian languages often also exhibit a certain type of external possession construction involving body parts and other part expressions, for which likewise analyses in terms of secondary predication structures have been proposed (see section 3.2).

subsection.heading: 1.2 A brief introduction to Australian languages
subsection.p: It is important to note that Australian languages do not form a homogeneous group either in terms of their genetic relationship or in terms of their typological characteristics. Research on the genetic subgrouping of Australian languages is still in progress; it is made more difficult by the complete lack of records dating before the invasion of Europeans, and the scarcity of documentation of the languages in some areas. Of the estimated 200–250 Australian languages at the time of first European contact (Walsh 1991, 1997), more than half are no longer spoken, and most of the remaining languages are severely endangered, especially if they are no longer acquired by children. The number of speakers rarely exceeds a few hundred people, and often only a dozen or fewer fluent speakers remain.

The by now widely accepted genetic division (cf. Blake 1988; Evans 1988 – but see Dixon 1997, 2002) is between the relatively coherent genetic group of Pama-Nyungan (henceforth PN) languages, covering most of the continent, and around 25 other language families – each comprising only a few languages – which are subsumed under the label Non-Pama-Nyungan (henceforth NPN) languages.

With regard to their morphological structure, most Australian languages are agglutinating with varying degrees of fusional characteristics, but some NPN languages, like Mayali (see example (4)), are strongly polysynthetic. Most languages are ‘non-configurational’ in the sense that the order of phrases is conditioned by pragmatic rather than syntactic factors. Word order within phrases may be restricted to varying degrees (see section 3.1). Most NPN languages have bound pronominals which are prefixed to the verb. Prefixing is only attested for very few PN languages; usually, these either lack bound pronominals altogether, or feature pronominal suffixes or enclitics (see section 3.1.1).

Australian languages have played a prominent role in the debate on ergativity – cf. Dixon (1979, 1994), Silverstein (1976), Bittner and Hale (1996a, 1996b), among many others. The majority of languages are indeed morphologically (but not necessarily syntactically) ergative. However, there are also languages of the accusative type, and in polysynthetic languages like Nunggubuyu (Heath 1984), core arguments are often unmarked for case (cf. also Baker 1996: 130–131).

The discussion in the remaining sections draws on a sample of languages from several language families with varying typological characteristics. Section 2 presents an overview of the morphological and syntactic properties of depictive secondary predicates in Australian languages. Section 3 reviews the contrasting ways in which the term ‘secondary predication’ has been applied in the analysis of Australian languages, and outlines some of the problems of delimiting secondary predicates from other construction types.

subsection.heading: 2 Morphological and syntactic properties of depictive secondary predicates in Australian languages
subsection.p: In the following subsections, only depictives that are adjuncts (in the traditional sense, not in the wider sense introduced in section 3.1.1) will be considered. Note, however, that in some of the polysynthetic NPN languages of northern Australia, such as Mayali, argument-oriented elements may be incorporated into the main predicate and in this case are constituents of a complex predicate rather than adjuncts. In (4a), the predicate nga-rrarrkid-ma-ng is a single phonological and grammatical word consisting of the verb stem and the incorporated predicate nominal -rrarrkid ‘alive’, which semantically predicates on the object. In (4b), the nominal yau ‘child’ is incorporated and may be interpreted as a secondary predicate (‘as a child’):

row.entry: ‘It's alive, I’ll pick it up alive.’
‘My mother left me with them as a child.’

subsection.heading: 2.1 Syntactic position
subsection.p: Little is known about the precise syntactic properties of depictive secondary predicates in Australian languages. While in English, depictives are usually analyzed as constituents of the VP and there is some controversy regarding the level of adjunction, e.g., of subject and object depictives (see chapter 58), many Australian languages lack evidence for the existence of a phrasal category verb phrase, and the word order of both arguments and adjuncts is rather variable. These properties have been subsumed under the label ‘non-configurationality’ (see section 3.1). The lack of a fixed position of the secondary predicate is in many Australian languages compensated for by extensive agreement; that is, the depictive indicates the relationship to its controller by agreement rather than position (see section 2.2).

In any case, an analysis in terms of syntactic position can only capture the status of the secondary predicate as an adjunct, but does not directly capture the relation between the secondary predicate and its controller (although it has been claimed for English that the position varies depending on whether the controller is a subject or an object). This second relation has sometimes been described in terms of dependency, e.g., by Mel’cuk (1988), Nichols (1978), and, with reference to Australian languages, by McGregor (1997: 54–56, 2005), who regards it as an attributive relationship. The nowadays more widely accepted analysis of depictives is that developed within the framework of predication theory. Here, the relationship between controller and depictive is analyzed as an instance of predication, which is considered to be an irreducible syntactic relationship (see chapter 58).

subsection.heading: 2.2 Agreement
subsection.p: Because of their argument-oriented nature, depictive secondary predicates are reminiscent of attributive modifiers in an NP. Therefore, in many languages a marking device that is typically used to establish coherence between the constituents of a noun phrase – agreement – is used to link a depictive to its controller (which does not have to be overtly expressed; see section 2.4). This phenomenon is well known from Ancient Greek and the Slavic and Romance languages (cf., e.g., Napoli 1975; Nichols 1978; Legendre 1990).

Many Australian languages also show extensive agreement of depictives with their controllers (this type of agreement has been termed ‘referential agreement’ by Dench and Evans 1988: 14–16). In ergative languages like Warlpiri, the depictive takes ergative marking if the controller is an actor in a transitive clause (5a), and absolutive marking (usually zero) if the controller is an undergoer in a transitive clause (5b), or the sole argument of an intransitive clause (cf. Simpson 1991: 199–214; Hale et al. 1995):

row.entry: ‘The dog is chasing the kangaroo tired.’
‘The dog is chasing the kangaroo (and the latter is) tired.’

subsection.p: In accusative languages like Martuthunira, agreement distinguishes depictives controlled by the (unmarked) nominative subject, as in (6), from those controlled by the accusative object, as in (2). Agreement is also attested for depictives with controllers in oblique cases (see section 2.4):

row.entry: ‘I would have grabbed [it] but it fell down dead.’

subsection.p: Since many Australian languages allow double case marking (Dench and Evans 1988; Plank 1995), case agreement is possible even if an adjunct already takes a case marker indicating its thematic role, such as the similative marker in (7). Here the phrase dimana-marraj ‘like a horse’ is marked as a depictive secondary predicate through agreement; in other words, it is construed as a predication on the man. A paraphrase that captures this relationship is ‘the man eats as if he was a horse (at the time of eating)’:

row.entry: ‘That man eats food like a horse.’

subsection.p: Double case marking resulting from agreement is also found on constituents which one might be inclined to analyze as adverbials, not as secondary predicates, on semantic grounds; for example, manyi-nhingi-ngga ‘after food’ in (8):

row.entry: ‘They could take you after (they have eaten) food.’ (lit.: ‘from food’)

subsection.p: Languages with extensive agreement on adjuncts thus raise the question whether agreement should be regarded as the major criterion for the status of an adjunct as a secondary predicate. In this case, even adjuncts like the one in (8) have to be regarded as secondary predicates. Alternatively, it may be possible to distinguish secondary predicates and adverbials on the basis of other formal properties (see section 3.3). A further problem arises in languages which allow discontinuous noun phrases, since depictive secondary predicates exhibiting agreement can no longer be distinguished from modifiers in a discontinuous noun phrase by word order alone (see section 3.1.2).

subsection.heading: 2.3 Secondary predication and switch-reference
subsection.p: Warlpiri and several other Australian languages exhibit a particular type of argument-oriented subordinate clause which has received some attention in the literature (cf. Austin 1981b; and for Warlpiri: Hale 1982: 290–294, 1986: 245–247; Simpson and Bresnan 1983; Simpson 1988, 1991: 314ff.; Hale et al. 1995). It is headed by a non-finite verb form (see also section 2.5.2) or (more rarely) by a nominal, followed by a suffix which simultaneously encodes relative tense (e.g., a simultaneous, anterior, or subsequent/purpose clause) and serves to identify the controller of the subordinate clause. Example (9) illustrates subordinate clauses interpreted as simultaneous (SIM) to the matrix clause in Warlpiri. In (9a), the subject complementizer (SCOMP) -karra indicates that the controller is a subject; in addition, the complementizer is here followed by the ergative case in agreement with a transitive subject. In both (9b) and (9c) the subordinate clause is controlled by the object of the matrix clause. The subordinate clause in (9b) does not take an overt agreement suffix because the controller is an unmarked absolutive object, but in (9c), it takes dative case in agreement with the dative object. Note that the ‘object complementizer (OCOMP)’ suffix -kurra in Warlpiri is identical to the allative case. This is not an accidental coincidence, because the use of the allative as a marker of object control is an areal feature which is also found in other northern Australian languages which are not necessarily related to each other, including Wardaman (Merlan 1994: 287–289; see example (23)), Jaminjung (Schultze-Berndt 2000: 112–113), Kaititj (Austin 1981b: 326), and Bilinarra (Nordlinger 1998: 165):

row.entry: ‘The man saw the kangaroo (while the man was) running.’
‘He takes money from his poor grandmother (while she is) asleep.’

subsection.p: Since these constructions are restricted to controllers in a specific function, they have been used as evidence of grammatical relations (subject and object) in languages like Warlpiri (see section 2.4). Moreover, the additional agreement marking suggests that subordinate clauses of the type illustrated in (9) function as depictive secondary predicates. This is indeed the analysis proposed by Simpson (1988, 1991), Laughren (1992), Hale (1994), and Hale et al. (1995). They choose the term ‘eventive’ secondary predicate (as opposed to stative secondary predicate) for this construction because of the additional component of relative tense (in this case, simultaneity). This component is clearly contributed by the suffix, not by the fact that the predicate is a deverbal form, as shown in (10), where the subordinate clause is headed by a nominal. Only (10a), where the secondary predicate is unmarked in agreement with the absolutive controller, and not (10b) can be interpreted as stating that the controller (the woman) is in a sick state. The object complementizer suffix -kurra in (10b) enforces an ‘eventive’ reading, captured in the translation as ‘involved with the sick one’:

row.entry: ‘The man saw the woman involved with the sick one.’

subsection.p: A number of authors, including Austin (1981b), Hale (1982, 1994) and Simpson and Bresnan (1983), on the other hand, have analyzed the same set of constructions as a same-subject construction and a different-subject construction (also termed ‘obviative’) in a switch-reference system. The subordinate clause marked by -karra indicates that its controller is the main clause subject, i.e., the two clauses have the same subject, whereas the subordinate clause marked by -kurra has a subject which is different from the main clause subject (i.e., a main clause object). In addition, Warlpiri also has two further contrasting markers of simultaneous subordinate clauses (Hale 1986). The first (-ngkarni/-rlarni, here simply glossed as SIM) allows a free choice of controller, although usually the controller is not a subject or object (11a). The second (-rlajinta, identical to the comitative case) may have the same subject (as in (11b)) or a different subject compared with the matrix clause, but encodes a simultaneous event which is, as it were, ‘accidentally’ simultaneous, and not ascribed to an argument in the main clause event (Simpson and Bresnan 1983: 60). Consequently, the first but not the second construction shows (optional) case agreement with the controller (compare (11b), with no ergative agreement, with (9a) above):

row.entry: ‘The man is trimming the boomerang for the child (while it is) at play.’
‘The man accidentally cut himself while trimming the boomerang.’

subsection.p: In functional terms, we are therefore dealing with a switch-reference system which does not just show a binary contrast between ‘same-subject’ and ‘different-subject’, but distinguishes between same-subject (-karra), subject = object (-kurra), and free-subject (-ngkarni/-rlarni) categories. In addition, these are in opposition to a non-controlled simultaneous clause (-rlajinta). Formally, the first three categories can also be analyzed as depictive secondary predicates controlled by the subject, the object, and a free controller, respectively, while the fourth type of subordinate clause, which does not exhibit a necessary relationship to a controller, is an adverbial. Thus, the analyses of Warlpiri non-finite subordinate clauses as switch-reference constructions and depictive constructions are complementary rather than contradictory. A similar system, where a switch-reference system can be seen as emerging from the contrast of various subordinate clause types with different control properties, is described for Martuthunira by Dench (1988, 1995: 240–262).

The secondary predicate analysis of a subordinate clause of this type is only warranted, however, when it is obligatorily controlled, i.e., when it cannot have its own subject. A true same-subject construction which is not a secondary predicate but an adverbial clause is found in the central Australian language Arrernte, although arguably the same-subject marker -le (which is identical to the ergative marker) represents a generalized former agreement marker (Wilkins 1988). Considering only (12a), one might be tempted to analyze the subordinate predicate as a true depictive secondary predicate which is followed by the ergative marker -le in agreement with the subject of the clause, just as in the Warlpiri example in (9a). However, (12b) shows that the subordinate predicate is not obligatorily controlled, since in the first line of (12b) it appears with its own subject:

row.entry: ‘The man cooked the meat while singing.’
‘When I wasn't working, I used to stay at home and look after the baby.’

subsection.heading: 2.4 The syntactic function of the controller
subsection.p: In English, depictives can be controlled by the subject of an intransitive or transitive predicate and by the object of a transitive predicate (cf., e.g., Aarts 1995: 76). This has sometimes been claimed to reflect a universal syntactic restriction, or alternatively, a restriction on the thematic role of potential controllers (e.g., to theme, agent, and patient; see chapter 58). However, languages differ considerably with regard to which arguments are easily accessible as controllers. For example, Finnish regularly allows oblique controllers (Nichols 1978: 120–121). Some variation in the restrictions on potential controllers is also found in Australian languages (cf. Dench and Evans 1988: 15), although it has to be said that in-depth research on these issues has been carried out only for very few languages. A number of Australian languages with a rich case system and obligatory agreement of secondary predicates also allow datives and other oblique arguments as controllers. In the Warlpiri example in (13), the controller is a dative object; agreement unambiguously signals that the locative phrase encodes the location of the baby, not the food (for locative phrases as secondary predicates, see also section 3.3):

row.entry: ‘The woman gives food to the baby in the coolamon (carrier dish).’

subsection.p: Similarly, example (14) shows that in Diyari, a locative-marked oblique argument can be the controller of a depictive: it is the child spoken to, not the speaker, that is described as having no clothes on:

row.entry: ‘I spoke to the child with no clothes on.’

subsection.p: In (15a), from Martuthunira, the controller is a directional adjunct marked with the allative case. Here the presence of the temporal clitic -l enforces a predicative reading of the phrase kupuyu-mulyarra; in other words, (15a) cannot just mean ‘I used to go to the little town’. The controller of the manner depictive in (15b) is the demoted agent in a passive construction, as indicated by the ‘effector’ case which in Martuthunira marks passive agents:

row.entry: ‘I used to go to town (when it was a) small (place).’
‘This fruit has been held in hand really tightly.’

subsection.p: Data from Australian languages thus raise problems for the claim that restrictions on the controllers of secondary predicates are universal. It seems more likely that the potential for functioning as a controller follows the accessibility hierarchy for grammatical relations (Keenan and Comrie 1977), as has been suggested by Nichols (1978: 120). The conditions under which oblique arguments and adjuncts can function as controllers remain a matter for further investigation.

Example (15b) also shows that the controller – in this case, the demoted agent – does not have to be overtly expressed. On the basis of comparable Warlpiri data, Laughren (1992) argues that the secondary predicate does not enter a predicative relation to a surface constituent of the clause, but rather to an argument in Lexical Conceptual Structure. Note that this observation is not restricted to Australian languages; in languages like German and English, likewise, depictives without overt controllers can be found, for example when the controller is an argument in an infinitival construction (e.g., in not to be eaten raw).

The conclusion that the controller is a semantic rather than a syntactic argument is further supported by the observation that agreement of secondary predicates, even in the case of overtly expressed controllers, is not simply a surface phenomenon resulting in identical case marking of two surface constituents. The case marking on the depictive reflects the semantic role of the controller rather than the marking of the corresponding NP constituent. For example, since ergative marking of agents in a transitive clause is optional in Gooniyandi (McGregor 1992b, 1998), the subject NP goornboo ‘woman’ in (16) is unmarked, whereas the depictive controlled by the subject takes ergative case:

Secondary predicates – more precisely non-finite subordinate clauses of the type discussed in section 2.3 – have also been used as one of the tests for the existence of grammatical relations like subject and object in the languages in question (in particular Warlpiri), including dative objects as in (9c). First, the non-finite subordinate clause is marked differently according to whether the controller is a subject, an object, or neither; and second, the non-overt, controlled argument always has to be the subject of the subordinate clause (cf. Hale 1982: 294, 1994; Simpson and Bresnan 1983; Simpson 1988, 1991: 314; Laughren 1989: 330–336, 1992: 202; Speas 1990: 160–162). Having clear syntactic tests for grammatical relations is, of course, important in languages where subject and object are identified neither by their syntactic position (because of the ‘non-configurational’ nature of the language in question) nor directly by case marking (because the language is, like Warlpiri, morphologically ergative).

subsection.heading: 2.5 Word class and internal structure of depictive secondary predicates
subsection.p: Depictive secondary predicates can be classified according to their marking (e.g., agreement – see section 2.2 – or marking for control and relative tense – see section 2.3), but they can also be subdivided according to their word class and internal structure. In this respect, too, one is forced by data from Australian languages to reconsider the range of constructions to be analyzed as secondary predicates.

subsection.heading: 2.5.1 Nominal and adjectival secondary predicates
subsection.p: In the standard examples found in the literature, e.g. (1), depictives are simple adjectives, and occasionally adjectival phrases. Not surprisingly, in Australian languages we also find corresponding examples where the secondary predicate is adjectival in that it encodes a temporary state or condition; examples are (2), (5), and (6).

It has often been claimed that only (adjectival) predicates encoding a temporary state, not predicates encoding a permanent quality or property, may function as depictives. Following Carlson (1977a), Stump (1985), and Kratzer (1995), the two types of predicates are also known as stage-level vs. individual-level predicates (see chapter 58). Compare (17a) and (17b):

(17)
a. The snake ate the mouse alive. (stage-level predicate)
b.
??The snake ate the mouse bony. (individual-level predicate)

In many Australian languages, though, there is no clear morphosyntactic distinction between adjectives, nouns, and adverbs, which are just subclasses of nominals. Consequently, both stage-level predicates and individual-level predicates, e.g., common nouns, can be used as depictives (cf. Hale 1983; Simpson 2005). In (18), the nominal ngarrka ‘man’ predicates on the object of a perception verb. As Hale (1983: 32) states, this interpretation “is perfectly natural in a variety of situations, including, for example, that in which the speaker sees a male person (formerly ‘a boy’) after his initiation (now ‘a man’. . . )”:

In English, as the translation of (18) shows, an NP has to be marked with as in order to serve as a secondary predicate. According to Stump (1985: 272–277), the predicative marker as is an explicit device turning individual-level predicates into stage-level predicates. Warlpiri, however, appears to lack this strict stage-level/individual-level distinction. (Note that the restriction of depictives to stage-level predicates has to be given up in any case if the version of the pronominal argument hypothesis is adopted according to which all lexical expressions are secondary predicates, or if ‘part’ expressions are also analyzed as depictives; see sections 3.1.1 and 3.2).

In addition to simple nominals and adjectivals, there are good reasons for also analyzing many types of case-marked noun phrases and adpositional phrases as secondary predicates; these are discussed in section 3.3.

subsection.heading: 2.5.2 Deverbal secondary predicates
subsection.p: In many languages, not only nominals but also non-finite verb forms can serve as depictive secondary predicates. This is well known for the so-called participles of English and many other European languages, which function just like adjectives in that they can be used as attributes, as main predicates, and as adjuncts (consider Joy arrived drunk, with a past participle functioning as secondary predicate). For non-finite verb forms which are restricted to adjunct function (but which cannot be used as attributes), the term converb has been suggested in the literature (cf. Haspelmath and König 1995).

Some Australian languages have a wide range of converb constructions. (Other languages do not have non-finite verb forms at all.) These converb constructions include not only simple deverbal predicates, but also more complex constructions, i.e., subordinate clauses. A subset of these can be identified as secondary predicates: first, by the fact that they are obligatorily controlled, i.e., they do not allow their subject to be overtly expressed; and second, by case agreement with their controller. However, in grammatical descriptions and theoretical accounts of these deverbal constructions, they are variously analyzed as adverbials, depictive secondary predicates, or subordinate clauses with switch-reference marking (see also section 2.3).

A possible objection to the analysis of obligatorily controlled converbs and converb clauses as secondary predicates is based on the fact that these deverbal forms typically express ‘relative tense’, e.g., simultaneity or anteriority. Standard depictives, on the other hand, express a temporary condition or state. In order to analyze converb constructions – especially when they show agreement with a controller – as depictive secondary predicates, one therefore either has to show that they encode a state despite the relative tense marking, or extend the notion of secondary predication.

Some authors recognize certain converb clauses as secondary predicates and use the term ‘eventive’ secondary predicate, e.g., for subordinate clauses in simultaneous interpretation (see section 2.3). A simultaneous converb, just like the present participle laughing in Joy left the party laughing, can be interpreted as encoding a state – the state of being in the process of (simultaneously) performing an event.

Similarly, an anterior deverbal predicate (such as the English past participle drunk) or a clause headed by an anterior form can be regarded as encoding a post-state of the event which is denoted by the lexeme from which it derives. This post-state holds simultaneously to the event encoded by the main predicate, and it is ascribed to the controller. In many Australian languages, anterior deverbal forms (just as in Latin and other Romance languages) agree in case with a controller. For example, in Kayardild, anterior deverbal predicates are formed by adding both a resultative suffix and a nominalizer (‘NR’) to the verb stem. The resulting forms can be used as simple depictives, as in (19a), and as heads of non-finite clauses functioning as depictives, as in (19b) (Evans 1995: 476–480):

row.entry: ‘That place (garden) is lovely (having been) worked on by daddy.’

subsection.p: Subordinate (converb) clauses encoding subsequent or intended events which show case agreement are also found in some Australian languages, including Kayardild (Evans 1995: 419–420), Yukulta (Keen 1983: 247), Warlpiri (Hale 1982: 281–289; Nash 1986: 261), and Yankunytjatjara (Goddard 1985). Most of these languages distinguish a purposive form marking personal intent (with agreement) from a general purposive (without agreement), which is used to indicate conventional, socially recognized purposes, and which is also found in ‘different subject’ expressions. The difference is illustrated in (20) for Yankunytjatjara. The general purposive marker -ku is shown in (20a) in ‘different subject’ function (the people who pour the petrol are not identical with the people who intend to return). In contrast to the general purposive, the ‘intentive’ marker -kitja always triggers agreement marking with the subject in absolutive or ergative case, respectively. It is used when the purpose of an activity is ascribed to the subject, and when, at the same time, this purpose is not obvious, i.e., when it is not conventionally recognized, but rather ascribed to the personal motivation of the agent. Thus, the ‘intentive’ indicates that getting firewood in (20b) and taking off the water pump in (20c) are the agent's personal intentions, non-obvious for others:

row.entry: ‘And he will pour (us) some (petrol) for returning (i.e., so that we can go home).’
‘The man went off (because he wanted) to get firewood.’
‘I took off the carburettor wanting the water pump (e.g., mistakenly removed the carburettor, or removed the carburettor to get at the water pump).’

subsection.p: The semantic contrasts involved suggest that the constituents marked by the specific ‘intention’ markers in Yankunytjatjara and other languages, but not those marked by the general purposive markers, are depictive secondary predicates. Semantically, it is the intention to bring about an event that is predicated on the controller, as indicated by agreement. Thus, while the event represented by the noun phrase or subordinate clause is in a sense subsequent to the event represented by the main predicate, the intention clearly holds simultaneously with the event expressed by the main predicate. The parallel behavior of nominalized verbs (20b) and underived nominals (20c) lends further support to a parallel analysis of nominal and deverbal depictives. (Note that intentive expressions of this type are analyzed as ‘subject-oriented NPs’ rather than as secondary predicates by Dench and Evans 1988: 17–18; however, the authors do not give clear reasons for the distinction, nor do they indicate which other expression types should be analyzed as subject-oriented NPs.)

subsection.heading: 2.5.3 Secondary predicates from other word classes
subsection.p: Australian languages also feature secondary predicates that are neither nominal nor (de)verbal. For some languages – e.g., Kayardild (Evans 1995: 231), Martuthunira (Dench 1995: 53), and Yankunytjatjara (Goddard 1985: 57–58) – a non-verbal word class restricted to predicative function has been described. Because its members take nominal inflections in agreement with a controller, these are sometimes subsumed under the class of nominals or adjectives. However, if nominals and adjectives are defined as a class of words that may be used in referential and attributive function, respectively, this term does not apply to the category in question, which is restricted to predicative use without showing the formal characteristics of verbs. Most of these predicates express a condition or a posture. An example from Kayardild is mibulka ‘asleep’, used as a depictive in (21) (the second depictive in this clause, malangarrba ‘drunk’, is a true adjective which may also be used attributively):

row.entry: ‘He speared your daddy (who was) asleep and drunk.’

subsection.p: In addition, Kayardild has a small class of lexemes which are not only inherently predicative, but restricted to depictive function. That is, words from this class are always used as adjuncts, and in this respect resemble adverbs, but they also obligatorily agree in case with one argument of the clause (Evans 1995: 227–229). Lexical items with similar properties have been described for Warlpiri (Hale 1982: 279–280) and Diyari (Austin 1981a: 107–108), although they are simply considered a subset of nominals by some authors (e.g., Hale 1983; Simpson 1991: 125–129). Semantically, they mainly comprise notions of manner. An example is parraparra ‘loud, energetic’ in Diyari, illustrated in (22):

A second type of nonverbal predicate constituting a distinct part of speech is also found in (mainly northern) Australian languages, including Warlpiri (Nash 1982; Simpson 1991), Jaru (Tsunoda 1981), Gija (Kofod 1996), Jaminjung (Schultze-Berndt 2000), Wardaman (Merlan 1994), and Wagiman (Wilson 1999). Predicates of this type, termed ‘coverbs’, ‘preverbs’, or ‘verbal particles’ in the literature, form an open class with possibly thousands of members. These differ in morphology and distribution from inflecting verbs (the latter form a closed class in most of these languages). They cannot form the main predicate of an independent main clause, and they only occur as part of a complex predicate together with an inflecting verb, or as the main predicate in a subordinate clause. Some of these subordinate clauses, in turn, can be analyzed as depictive secondary predicates. An example from Wardaman is given in (23). In (23a), the unmarked positional verbal particle mugurn ‘lie, sleep’ forms a complex predicate with an inflecting verb (which happens to be roughly synonymous). In (23b), the same verbal particle takes the allative case, which here, as in Warlpiri (see section 2.3), has an object complementizer function. The resulting expression is a subordinate clause functioning as an object-controlled depictive:

row.entry: ‘He left me sneakingly (while I was) asleep.’

subsection.p: To summarize: in Australian languages, parts of speech found in secondary predicate function include not only nominals and adjectivals, but also deverbal predicates, the verbal particles (or preverbs/coverbs) found in the northern area, and, in some languages, a class of ‘manner nominals’ which show obligatory case agreement but only appear in adjunct position and can therefore be analyzed as a distinct part of speech restricted to depictive function. Likewise, the internal complexity of the secondary predicate may vary; there is some evidence that case-marked NPs or adpositional phrases and subordinate clauses should be considered depictives.

subsection.heading: 3.1 Secondary predication and non-configurationality
subsection.p: Australian languages, and in particular Warlpiri, have played a prominent role in discussions of non-configurationality, e.g., Blake (1983), Hale (1983, 1989, 1992, 1994), Jelinek (1984), Heath (1986), Nash (1986), Laughren (1989), Speas (1990), Simpson (1991), Austin and Bresnan (1996), Baker (1996, 2001), and Austin (2001). Many Australian languages have properties which contrast sharply with the properties of configurational languages such as English: they have free word order, they freely allow zero anaphora (i.e., omission of lexical arguments), and clauses have a ‘flat’ syntactic structure (i.e., there is no evidence for a category verb phrase). While it has recently been recognized that non-configurationality is not a unified phenomenon (cf. Austin and Bresnan 1996; Baker 2001), these features were originally conceived of as being in correlation. The formulation of a Configurationality Parameter (Hale 1983) was based on languages like Warlpiri where these features do in fact coincide.

Jelinek (1984) proposes to link free word order and zero anaphora, as well as a number of other phenomena such as split case marking, to the presence of clitic pronominals in Warlpiri. According to Jelinek's proposal, known as the pronominal argument hypothesis, bound or clitic pronominals have argument status in non-configurational languages, while the corresponding noun phrases are analyzed as adjuncts which are licensed by the pronominal arguments but which do not have argument status themselves. Building on this analysis, it has occasionally been argued that the adjunct noun phrases are in fact secondary predicates (section 3.1.1).

Languages which exhibit another feature often associated with non-configurationality – the possibility of discontinuous expressions – pose a further problem for the theory of secondary predication. This is the problem of distinguishing between attributes in a discontinuous noun phrase and depictive secondary predicates (section 3.1.2).

subsection.heading: 3.1.1 The status of nominal expressions in non-configurational languages
subsection.p: Jelinek (1984) suggests that in head-marking non-configurational languages like Warlpiri, only the clitic pronominals – which in (24) are attached to the tensed auxiliary – have argument status, not the nominal expressions (e.g., maliki ngaju-nyangu ‘my dog’ and kuyu ‘meat’ in (24)). Under this analysis, a configurational structure for a clause like (24) can be maintained:

row.entry: ‘I am giving meat to my dog.’

subsection.p: Jelinek's proposal has later been modified (e.g., by Baker 1996) to the effect that the real arguments are empty categories (pro) which license agreement of the bound or clitic pronominals. Under both versions of the pronominal argument hypothesis, various solutions have been proposed for the status of the overt nominal expressions. Jelinek (1984) originally analyzed them as adjuncts which are ‘ad-argumental’ because they are co-indexed with a (pronominal) argument. Speas (1990: 165–170) then suggests – again, with reference to Warlpiri – that they could be analyzed as secondary predicates, conceived of as modifiers undergoing theta-merger of their argument with one of the arguments in the verbal grid. This analysis relies on the presence of case markers – considered as argument-taking predicates – in Warlpiri and related languages.

Baker (2001) defends the secondary predicate analysis of overt nominal expressions in non-configurational languages, at least for languages of the Warlpiri type, which he distinguishes from languages whose non-configurational properties result from scrambling or dislocation. One of Speas's and Baker's main arguments in support of the secondary predicate analysis is that this type of structure is needed, in any case, in order to account for the use of nominals as secondary predicates in Warlpiri in examples like (18). Baker (2001: 428–433) further claims that because of the lack of a distinction between nouns and adjectives in Warlpiri (see section 2.5.1), all nominals are really adjectival, i.e., “good predicates” and “bad arguments.” He explicitly recognizes that this proposal extends the notion of secondary predication far beyond the traditional notion (note that in this approach, maliki ngaju-nyangu ‘my dog’ and kuyu ‘meat’ in (24) are assigned the same status as alive in the snake ate the mouse alive). Consequently, the restriction that only stage-level predicates can function as depictive secondary predicates (see section 2.5.1) has to be given up. Baker also recognizes that in this account depictive secondary predicates in English and in Warlpiri differ strikingly in their pragmatic function and communicative effect.

Speas's and Baker's analysis therefore deviates from Hale's. Hale (1983) explicitly distinguishes the predicative and the referential or “argumental” use of nominal expressions (thus, he states that (18) also has a second reading ‘I see a man’). He also states that the class of nominals/adjectives spans a continuum from items that are more likely to be used referentially (such as determiners or free pronominals) to items that are more likely to be used predicatively, even though he also remarks that the predicative use is much more pervasive in Warlpiri than in English. Nordlinger (1998: 40–41) also cites the existence of “nominals” restricted to secondary predicate function (see section 2.5.3) as evidence against the secondary predicate analysis of all nominal expressions.

Austin and Bresnan (1996), Nordlinger (1998: 34–43), and Austin (2001) raise several other objections to the adjunct analysis of overt nominal expressions. One is that in some languages at least, some types of overt nominals are obligatory (and hence cannot be adjuncts), e.g., dative indirect objects of verbs like ayani ‘search’ in Wambaya, which, as (25) shows, are not cross-referenced by a bound pronominal:

row.entry: ‘(My) sister is looking for a man.’

subsection.p: It seems that despite the advantages of the secondary predicate analysis of nominal expressions in non-configurational languages, the ramifications of this proposal for the theory of secondary predication have to be given more careful consideration.

subsection.heading: 3.1.2 Depictives vs. attributes in a discontinuous noun phrase
subsection.p: Under one definition of non-configurationality, the phenomenon of discontinuous noun phrases is considered an important characteristic of non-configurational languages (cf. Hale 1983). As Austin and Bresnan (1996) have shown, though, not all Australian languages that allow free order of phrases also allow discontinuous noun phrases. In those that do, this raises a problem for the distinction between depictive secondary predicates and attributive modifiers, since it can no longer be drawn in terms of word order alone (Dench and Evans 1988: 14; Schultze-Berndt and Himmelmann 2004: 81–84).

A widely accepted proposal, at least in the Australianist literature, was pioneered by Hale (1981a). This is that attributes in discontinuous noun phrases may have either a ‘merged’ (i.e., restrictive) or an ‘unmerged’ (i.e., non-restrictive) reading. Both are illustrated in (26):

row.entry: a.‘The/a big dog bit me.’ (merged interpretation)
b.‘The/a dog bit me and it was big.’ (unmerged interpretation)

subsection.p: A number of authors, including Nash (1986), Simpson (1991), and Nordlinger (1998), have proposed that non-restrictive attributes should be analyzed just like secondary predicates. It is, however, also possible that the two types of constructions can be distinguished by prosodic means. Austin (1981a: 108) claims that the Diyari clause in (27) with sentence stress on nganhthi has the attributive reading, but with a slight intonation break after nganhthi and stress on thungka, it has the secondary predicate reading. Similar suggestions have been made by McGregor (1992a: 316) and Hale (1994: 193):

The prosodic properties of discontinuous modifiers in comparison with depictives, and the distinction between non-restrictive modifiers and depictive secondary predicates, remain a matter for further investigation.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Part–whole expressions
subsection.p: There exists a further construction type that has been analyzed as an instance of secondary predication by some authors. In many Australian languages, the preferred way to express the idea that a body part is involved in an event is to treat its ‘possessor’ as a core argument, i.e., as an external possessor (cf. Dixon 1980: 293; McGregor 1985, 1999; Blake 1987: 94ff.; and several contributions in Chappell and McGregor 1996). The body part (understood in a wide sense, i.e., including other inalienable part–whole relations like names, shadows, etc.) is represented as an additional noun phrase which shows case agreement with the possessor expression. In languages with bound pronominals or pronominal clitics, the possessor can be identified as the core argument or ‘syntactically active’ argument in that it triggers pronominal agreement. The phenomenon is illustrated in (28) with data from Warrwa for a transitive and an intransitive verb, respectively:

row.entry: ‘He touched me on the hand.’ (lit.: ‘he touched me hand’)
‘I've got a sore head.’ (lit.: ‘I do/am sore my-head’)

subsection.p: The grammatical status of the ‘part’ expression in constructions like these (e.g., nimala ‘hand’ in (28a) and nga-lma ‘my head’ in (28b)) has been a matter of debate in the literature. It has been described both as part of the same noun phrase as the ‘whole’ expression, and as a separate constituent (cf. Blake 1987: 95ff.). Of those authors who consider the ‘part’ expression a separate constituent, some follow Hale (1981b) in the view that it functions as a secondary predicate (e.g., Hale 1983: 39–40; Laughren 1992; Ogawa 2001). Indeed, a property that ‘part’ expressions in this type of construction share with secondary predicates in the narrow sense is the existence of a semantic relationship between an argument of the main predicate and the additional constituent. In the Australian languages under discussion, this semantic relationship is also formally reflected by case agreement.

However, there are also good reasons for distinguishing ‘part’ expressions and secondary predicates. The secondary predicate analysis has been most explicitly criticized by McGregor (1985), who raises the objection that a ‘part’ expression can never serve as a main predicate, and is thus not, intuitively, a predicate (the paraphrase ‘he touched me and I am a hand’ is as semantically deviant in the Australian languages in question as it is in English). Moreover, what is true of the part is not necessarily true of the whole; in other words, the ‘part’ expression is not optional, as in the case of true secondary predication. Rather, according to McGregor (1985: 210), the ‘part’ expression “specifies the EXTENT or LOCUS of the argument's involvement in the action.” Harvey (1996) and Schultze-Berndt (2000: 184–186) also reject the secondary predicate analysis of ‘part’ expressions. Dench and Evans (1988: 13–18), likewise, distinguish the two construction types, although both are subsumed under constructions showing “referential agreement.”

subsection.heading: 3.3.1 Manner expressions
subsection.p: As shown in sections 2.1 and 2.2, the traditional notion of secondary predication has been extended in a number of ways in order to account for phenomena in Australian languages. Another problem encountered in the analysis of Australian languages is the difficulty of drawing a borderline between adverbials and secondary predicates. For example, in a number of languages expressions which would normally be classified as manner adverbials on semantic grounds belong to a word class restricted to predicative function or even secondary predicate function and show obligatory case agreement (see section 2.5.3). An example of a manner secondary predicate from Diyari is given in (22); another example, from Yankunytjatjara, is given in (29):

Dench and Evans (1988: 14–15) distinguish “ascriptive” and “adverbial” secondary predicates, on the basis of the semantic type of adjunct expression and whether it can, in principle, serve as the main predicate in a non-verbal clause. Schultze-Berndt and Himmelmann (2004) and Himmelmann and Schultze-Berndt (2005) present a cross-linguistic survey of adjunct types which have the properties of depictives at least in some languages. On the basis of agreement phenomena in Australian and other languages, they conclude that many expression types may be construed as either argument-oriented (and consequently encoded as secondary predicates) or event-oriented (and consequently encoded as adverbials). In addition to manner expressions and also those types of subordinate ‘adverbial’ clauses discussed in section 2.3, there are several other expression types that are encoded as secondary predicates in at least some Australian languages. These include quantifiers (McGregor 2005), comitative phrases, (30–31), similative phrases, (7) and (16), locative and directional phrases, (32–33), and even temporal phrases, (34). All examples illustrate agreement of the adjunct constituent in question with one argument of the main predicate, usually the subject.

subsection.heading: 3.3.2 Comitative expressions
subsection.p: Comitative expressions, when construed as secondary predicates, e.g., by agreement marking, make explicit the relationship between the comitative argument and the argument of the clause that is said to be accompanied (usually, but not necessarily the subject). An example is (30) from Warlpiri:

row.entry: ‘The child, with the woman, is winnowing mulga seed.’

subsection.p: For Kayardild (Evans 1995: 420) and the related language Yukulta (Keen 1983: 247–248; Evans 1995: 421), agreement even extends to the ‘theme’ participant of verbs of transfer (i.e., the transferred entity) in some cases. The verbs of giving and deprivation in these languages allow for a number of case frames, among them one where the ‘theme’ takes proprietive case (a marker of concomitance). As shown in (31), this is followed by ergative marking in agreement with the transitive subject. According to Evans (1995: 420), this case frame “stresses the ownership by SUBJ of the thing transferred, either before (‘give’) or after (‘deprive’) the transfer”:

li.p:
Yukulta (Tangkic, NPN):
Kunawuna-nganda wuu-ja kulthangarr-urlu-ya.
child.ACC-1SG.SBJ:PAST give-ACTUAL flying.fox-PROP-ERG
‘I gave the child a flying fox.’ (lit.: ‘I presented the child with a flying fox’) (Keen 1983: 248)

subsection.heading: 3.3.3 Locative and directional expressions
subsection.p: The fact that locative expressions are not necessarily event-oriented (in that they indicate the location of an event as a whole), but can also have an argument-oriented reading (in that they indicate the location of only one of the arguments in an event), has occasionally been noted in the literature, e.g. by Müller-Bardey (1990), Takezawa (1993: 55), and Maienborn (2001). In Warlpiri, a locative expression may (optionally) show case agreement with a controller, as illustrated in (13) and (32). In (32), the man and the boomerang are in the same place, but the location is ascribed to the man, probably because he corresponds to the more prominent argument:

row.entry: ‘The/a man is trimming the boomerang in the/a camp.’

subsection.p: Not only locative expressions but also directional expressions can be understood as predicating on one of the arguments of the main predicate. In (33), the interpretation is that the man is in the state of being oriented in the direction of the sandhill:

row.entry: ‘The man left the children on his way to the sandhill.’

subsection.heading: 3.3.4 Temporal expressions
subsection.p: Temporal expressions constitute the perhaps most puzzling case of expressions whose formal make-up, in at least some languages, suggests an analysis as depictive secondary predicates. Temporal expressions are generally considered a paradigm case of event-oriented adverbials. Still, it is well known that they may agree with an argument of the main predicate in Ancient Greek and in Latin. Some Australian languages, too, have a class of temporal nominals which, at least optionally, agree with the subject in (ergative or absolutive) case. In Warlpiri, this class contains, among others, the terms jalangu ‘today’ and pirrarni ‘yesterday’ (cf. Hale 1982: 281). The latter is illustrated in (34):

With regard to Warlpiri examples such as (34), Simpson (1991: 208–209) and also Nordlinger (1998: 118–121) maintain that the temporal expressions are adjuncts which modify the whole clause and do not stand in a depictive relation to the subject. These authors claim that the ergative case on these expressions merely indicates that the clause as a whole contains an ergative subject. Hale (1982: 281), on the other hand, suggests that temporal expressions of this type could be analyzed as depictives, considering that “an entity can be located in a time as well as in a place.”

subsection.heading: 4 Conclusion
subsection.p: If one considers all models and proposals that have been put forward in the analysis of Australian languages, the label ‘secondary predicate’ has been used for a wide range of construction types, including lexical nominal expressions coreferential with the ‘pronominal arguments’ in non-configurational languages, ‘part’ expressions in external possession constructions, and many types of adjuncts (including subordinate clauses) which exhibit case agreement with one of the arguments of the main predicate. These include a number of expressions that are traditionally analyzed as adverbials on semantic grounds. Australian languages, thus, provide a good test case for any theory of secondary predication, and show particularly clearly that despite the considerable research efforts in recent years, we still lack a universally applicable definition of secondary predicates.
